Award.AwardTitle: 2018 Workshop: Quantum Biology and Quantum Processes in Biology

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The study and identification of quantum phenomena in biological systems is an interdisciplinary field that has attracted increasing attention in the past few decades, but has slowly progressed in part due to different background of physical scientists and biologists. This workshop will bring young and senior scientists together from different scientific disciplines including biology, physics, chemistry, and quantum information science to discuss processes in biology that require quantum theory, like chemical reactions, charge transport, and quantum biological phenomena, where the quantum process is used by the biological system for a particular function, such as magneto reception, photon absorption in vision, and photosynthesis. The workshop will contribute toward defining current important topics and questions to be addressed with future research, and will stimulate and possibly identify new research topics of quantum phenomena in biological systems with applications in quantum information science and condensed matter physics.

This workshop is co-funded by the Molecular Biophysics Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences in the Biological Sciences Directorate and the Physics of Living Systems Program in the Division of Physics in the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Workshop on "Quantum Biology and Quantum Processes in Biology" was held on November (25) 26-27, 2018 in Tysons Corner, VA.

The overarching objective of the workshop was to provide a forum for disseminating information and sharing ideas about our current understanding of the role of quantum mechanics in biology. The workshop included roughly 25 scientists drawn from biology, physics, chemistry, and quantum information to discuss processes in biology whose understanding require quantum theory, (such as electron transport), and  to discuss biological phenomena, where quantum mechanics may be used by a biological system for a particular function, i.e. magnetoreception, vision, photosynthesis, neuro-cognition, bioenergetics, olfaction and enzymatic reactions.  The role of quantum entanglement in biology was discussed as well.

 The workshop was motivated by the observation that although this interdisciplinary field has attracted increasing attention in the past few decades, the understanding of the role of quantum phenomena in biological systems is far from satisfactory. This is in part due to different backgrounds of physical scientists and biologists, but also due to a relative dearth of well-defined examples where quantum effects could be unambiguously demonstrated.

Workshop Program can be found at:

http://physicsoflivingsystems.org/workshop-quantum-biology-and-quantum-processes-in-biology/

Current Status

The two areas in which non-trivial quantum effects in biology are clear-cut are electron and hydrogen tunneling as they occur in enzyme function. Here, it seems likely that coherence is created transiently so as to enable wave function overlap and that protein structure and conformational motions will play a role in this process. On the other hand, tunneling-based mechanism in olfaction has long been controversial, but recent experimental data suggests that at least some fraction of olfactory receptors might function as vibrational detectors, making this application very promising.

The role of biologically-evolved coherence also seems very promising for magnetoreception, in which long-lived spin coherences in cryptochromes may enable magnetic sensing in animals and plants. Similarly, coherence seems relevant for the light harvesting complex in photosynthesis, where a tight and precise arrangement of chromophores may create long-lived mixed electronic-vibrational coherences. In these systems, the question of  "how long-lived?" still remains to be resolved.

Long-lived spin-coherences are also suggested to be involved in ROS production and Bioenergetics, but the issue of spin relaxation of the molecular oxygen radical has to be theoretically and experimentally addressed to make this new emerging area more promising for quantum effects in biology. The involvement of coherences has also been theoretically suggested in vision, and experiments to prove or disprove this theory are needed. Even more speculatively, the idea of long-lived nuclear spins in brain chemistry is also very interesting though obviously also very controversial. It would be a tremendous breakthrough if any of the presented conjectures on quantum processing in the brain turn out to be even partially correct.

Connected in a general way to the idea of coherence is the idea of quantum entanglement. Although it seems possible in the lab to engineer quantum entanglement between a living bacteria and quantized light, there is no evidence to date that suggests that living systems have evolved the ability to use entanglement for a functional purpose. Thus this remains an interesting but unproven suggestion.   

In all these areas - excluding enzyme function - there remains a disconnect between theory and experiment. This needs to be fixed by developing experimental systems that can directly test for specific quantum phenomena and discriminate classical from quantum effects.

The development of two-dimensional electronic spectroscopy and femtosecond X-ray free-electron lasers, might provide very powerful new tools for the development of this field. This will also be aided by developing more biologically realistic models. Furthermore, there is the need of scientists capable of working across disciplines from biology to chemistry and physics.

An overarching recommendation is for the National Science Foundation to support fundamental research in this emerging field of quantum biology and focus on studies that directly address the following points: 

  • There is the need to develop new experimental approaches that can convincingly distinguish non-classical from classical states and enable causal connections to be drawn between quantum effects at the atomic scale and macroscopic functional outputs. Some of these approaches may be facilitated by borrowing from optical and spectroscopic approaches widely used in the quantum optics and spintronics community.
  • There is the need to develop more biologically realistic theoretical models that can reproduce the observed behavior, assess its quantum or classical nature, and ultimately test the importance of any quantum characteristics to biological function.
  • It is important to recognize the multi-disciplinary nature of this research field and the need to promote and facilitate the collaboration of researchers from all relevant disciplines, with inclusion of both physicists and biologists being mandatory.
  • The net should be cast as wide as possible, with high-risk, high-reward projects given priority, that manifestly prove or disprove the importance of quantum mechanics in biological functions.
